title: Data in Galaxy
blurb: How to get datasets into Galaxy, and modify them once they're imported.
intro: Obtaining data in Galaxy is simple. You may upload from your machine, retrieve from a url, via ftp, or from any of several linked databases. Further, you may use shared data by accessing our ‘shared data libraries’ and ‘shared histories’.

topics.title: Importing via Data Uploader
topics.intro: Loading in data from your machine or via URL.

slides.text: The upload button can be found on the top of the toolbar to the left of the screen.
Click the upload icon to bring up the data importer.
The data importer is made up of a central pane, a set of import methods, mechanisms, and metadata inputs.
Click the 'Choose local files' button to select files from your machine.
Click the 'Choose FTP files' button to import files via ftp.
Click the 'Paste/Fetch data' button to input a url for a dataset or add text to be uploaded as a file by itself.
After clicking the 'Paste/Fetch data' button, paste text or a url in the field to specify data.

slides.alt: Pasted data in the url input
slides.text: You may also put multiple URLs at once, one per line.
Set the metadata of file type or genome assembly on upload for each file individually, or for all at once.
Click 'start' to begin the data import.
Alternatively, the rule-based uploader can be used to upload many files at once, or data from a tabular file.

slides.alt: Pasted data in the rule-based uploader
slides.text: Simply paste your tabular data into the rule-based text input and click 'build'.

slides.alt: Set rules in the left column
slides.text: Set rules to be applied to the table in the left column.

slides.alt: Data appears in the history once imported
slides.text: Once your data begins importing, it will appear in the history column to the right. It will appar grey while the import is pending, yellow while it is running, red if there is an error, and green when complete and ready to be used in an analysis.

topics.title: Retrieving Data from Public Databases
topics.header: Importing from Public Databases in Galaxy
topics.intro: Use data from sources such as UCSC, SRA, or EMBL.

slides.text: To retrieve data from a linked database, click on the 'Get Data' row in the toolbar to the left.
The expanded get data section shows the full list of integrated databases, accessible by clicking their tool.
Many of these tools use a standard Galaxy tool form to access the data. Input the requested data here in a format based on the tool's help sections to retrieve files.
Other databases, such as the UCSC data browser, are integrated in such a way as to temporarily redirect you directly to their interface.
Once the database's forms have been filled out, you will have the option to export data to Galaxy. Click that button to complete the request and return to the Galaxy home page.
All data imported in these methods will appear in your history and turn green when fully downloaded and ready to use.

topics.title: Obtaining Shared Data
topics.intro: Find and retrieve data shared between Galaxy users.

slides.text: The shared data tab is accessible from the masthead
From the drop down, users have acces to both the data libraries and histories shared across users on the server.
Clicking the data library row will show you a list of all avalilable shared data libraries.
Many shared data libraries have sub-directories. You can select entire directories to import.
By clicking on directories, you can choose individual files to import.
Use the checkboxes on the left to choose which files or directories to import.
Click the 'Export to History' button to select the format in which to retrieve selected data.

slides.alt: Choose existing or new history for files.
slides.text: Having selected format, either choose a new or existing history into which to import the data, then click 'Import'.

slides.alt: Data appears in the selected history
slides.text: Imported data will appear in the specified history.
Alternatively, you can access the published histories from the same tab on the masthead.
Selecting a history, all availailable files are able to be viewed and searched in the same manner as the normal history bar.

slides.alt: About this history. Click plus to import.
slides.text: Information on the history is available in the column on the right. To import this data, click the plus botton at the top-right of the column.
Name the history for the imported files, then click import. As before, the data will appear in the specified history.
The history panel to the right of the screen shows all datasets and files used in the current analysis. You can create a new history or switch to a previous one using the buttons at the top.
Click a dataset in the history to expand it. Expanded items have a quick view panel for the associated dataset, as well as more options on how to interact with the history item.
Click the eye to open the file as readible in the center panel.
Click the 'i' icon to view information about the dataset and the job/tool/command that generated it.
Clicking the pencil icon will take you to the metadata page.
From the Attributes tab, you can edit metadata, such as the genome assembly of the data, and add notes/anotations.
The Convert tab allows you to run basic tools to convert between similar datatypes (i.e. txt and tsv).
On the Datatypes tab, you can manually set the datatype without altering the file, if, for example, the automatic filetype detector failed to set properly (such as a tsv file set as a txt).
